favourite.article: I heard this hymn sung for the first time at my father's funeral in 1994 - it has since become one of my favourite hymns. I agree with the prophet Malachi that, rain or shine, poverty or plenty, we must praise the Lord.
This song I learnt in my secondary school days, even up till now I am still enjoying it. Yes, He who feeds the raven will also give His bread. Praise the Lord.
Surely our faithful God will never fail. He who feeds the ravens will give His people bread. Jehovah Rophi, breath healing on us, Lord. Our God is more than able.
I love this song though not with this tune. It's assurance is clear. It comes with a lot of healing and challenge to trust in God.
I prefer the tune, "Petition" by Franz Josef Haydn, which is what most hymnals use. The tune used here by Doane is too fast for the "holy contemplation" of this hymn.
This is one hymn that lifts my spirits each time I hear or sing it.
This song was one of my late dad's favourites, in the hymn-book, I find it soul-lifting, each time I go thru the verses.
I love this hymn, it has been a blessing to my soul during difficult times.
Soul lifting hymn. God of our fathers!
Oh my God! I'm alwys lifted each time I sing or hear this hymn. Inspirational and motivational.
I always feel lifted any time I sing this hymn. Truly awesome!

The tune, Bently is the more traditional tune for this hymn. When I am confused or without illusion I sing this hymn and others that are related. They lift my spirit and I am calmed. I actually long to go back to the choir.
This is a song which brings comfort in times when seeking His healing hands. My grandma woke up from a coma singing this song. Praise His holy name.

This is not the tune of this song that I know but it is a song that gives me assurance that God will break through and bring light in my hours of darkness or need. I get filled with hope that He who feeds the ravens will give bread to his children.
